markdownRemark.excerpt: Diverge #6 divergeweekly ‚ÄúThe future is unwritten. there are best case scenarios. There are worst-case scenarios. both of them are great fun to write about if‚Ä¶

children.value:
‚ÄúThe future is unwritten. there are best case scenarios. There are worst-case scenarios. both of them are great fun to write about if you‚Äô re a science fiction novelist, but neither of them ever happens in the real world. What happens in the real world is always a sideways-case scenario. World-changing marvels to us, are only wallpaper to our children.‚Äù
‚Äï

padding-bottom: 56.26009693053311%; position: relative; bottom: 0; left: 0; background-image: url('data:image/jpeg;base64,'); background-size: cover; display: block;

children.value: This will be a quick one relative to some of the essays I‚Äôve been writing recently.

I‚Äôve been reading and thinking about foresight ‚Äî especially as it relates to the current pandemic and security. As a result, I‚Äôve been getting interested in the human-made inevitability of prediction and wanted to explore that briefly.
With the rise of platform empires, we‚Äôve effectively
ceded the original vision of the internet as a distributed space
. Battle after battle of the free internet was lost to convenience, monetization strategies that drove consolidation, and
the pens, mice, and post-its of designers locked in market-driven competition

. Some of the most interesting conversations one can have on this are with Facebook designers who are both critical thinkers (which applies to many of those I‚Äôve met) and who are anxious about the impact of what they‚Äôve helped create. Yet they find themselves captured through unvested stock, individual loyalties within their teams, and the completely legitimate hypothesis that they might be able to make things better.
I don‚Äôt really know the answer on this one.
We‚Äôre all culpable for the internet that we lost

, and there‚Äôs some very good designers at the platform giants ‚Äî good in skill and good in soul ‚Äî who we shouldn‚Äôt throw under the bus. But I do think there‚Äôs a meaningful discussion to be had around this idea of capture and recognizing when we ARE captured.
I read an article recently by Patrick Porter on
how the British national security apparatus undermined its own foresight efforts by unconsciously insisting on confidence in their capacity to handle whatever might come

. This very idea is pathological: that they might both acknowledge the magnitude of the unknowns they faced, and still feel require confidence that we can wrangle it given our current preparedness. Britain isn‚Äôt alone in this, of course. If you‚Äôre developing a product, you‚Äôll experience microcosms of this every day: the feature or design decision you made just doesn‚Äôt glom on to reality. Your user or customer is frustrated, their user or customers are confused ‚Äî all because your synthesis of their needs and your own sensibility missed its mark. The difference lies in the speed of iteration.

A designer can (usually) quite easily test their hypothesis. Find a customer, set up a prototype, launch a test, or simply watch how your (possibly socially distanced) neighbour interacts with it. But of course it‚Äôs not so easy for a state‚Äôs national security establishment. Usually, national security institutions are pretty brilliant when it comes to punching through their own biases, using tools like
and others to explore alternative scenarios. But as
Micah Zenko‚Äôs book on Red Teaming points out
, the role of the Red Team can often be institutionally undermined in subtle ways:
be it explicitly walking back a decision during a war game
tacitly signalling leadership‚Äôs dissatisfaction with the results

. In both cases,  the act of simulating alternative options ‚Äî of diverging from the current mode of thought ‚Äî becomes dramatically constrained by the needs and fears of the commissioning institutions. It‚Äôs effectively nullified.

I think the same thing happens to the sensibility of designers captured by institutions. The scope of potential divergence becomes naturally constrained by the needs of the institutions they serve, and so their sensibility
is reinforced and narrowed along those lines over time

. And I think this is part of what I want Diverge Weekly to combat. This capture is a reflection of a point in time for an individual or a class of designers where the aperture is narrowing. But I‚Äôd like to believe it can still be opened.
So if the intent is to widen that aperture, functionally how do we start to open it again?
The third wave of the coronavirus pandemic is now - The Boston Globe
Scott Gottlieb on how life and the economy recovers from the crisis
Developing pandemic preparedness in Europe in the 21st century: experience, evolution and next steps

Example of the model I described in the main essay
South Asia:
Exploring Foresight, Epidemiology and the Coronavirus Pandemic with Dr. Peter Black * Journal of Futures Studies
In Rural Japan, a 370-Year-Old Tradition Falls to One Child - The New York Times
Millennium Challenge: The Real Story of a Corrupted Military Exercise and its Legacy

Design Strategy with Frog in Shanghai

children.value: ‚Äôs photography from the West African Ebola Crisis of 2014 won the Pullitzer prize, and captured an horrifying regional crisis. I‚Äôve been both reading more broadly but also searching for photography of the current pandemic trying to wrap my head around the chaos others are experiencing relative to the calm (save for a wonderful but berserk 1yr old) of my day-to-day in Denmark. I‚Äôd seen Berehulak‚Äôs photos before, but spent some more time with them while writing this.
Please give them a look here

children.value: Julia is an incredible design leader who I first met in San Francisco. Originally from France and married to an American, she worked with my wife, Ayla, at Adaptive Path before its acquisition in Capital One. She mentored and supported many emerging designers before and after that transition, and left an incredible legacy of support with that team. She‚Äôs also the catalyst for our ending up in Copenhagen, as she helped start the Fjord Copenhagen studio and quite effectively recruited Ayla to move to Europe in early 2017.

Julia is a model of what a global designer can be: someone with experience and empathy across cultures and language, co-designing a space for herself and her family where there are interesting problems and opportunities. I‚Äôve been hugely inspired watching her cultivate design communities wherever she goes, and the fact that her team members will move around the world for the chance to work with her again is a testament to what great design leadership looks like.
Every day is Tuesday, but today is Tuesday. Strength. Together-ish. # COVID19 # StayHome
